SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing at your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Robert Richardson
2. Your address: Box 242, Kisbey, Sask.
3. Date: March 23, 1963
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, stating dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question. If you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
9. What were your reasons for coming West?

My dad liked where we were and I was anxious to come.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

Railroad or Government Information?

The book. Also the Geography at school.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

No. 2

FLOWER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and places names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. If you rather have someone else do the writing of your dictation, this is quite acceptable.

1. Your full name: Robert Richardson
2. Your address: Box 242, Yisbay, Sask.
3. Date: March 22, 1953
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (If you do not read "no" to this question, if I would rather not or you may use "I was a small child," note "small child")
9. What were your reasons for coming West?

"I had Uncle Henry and was very anxious to come"

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)

"I learned about the West through government information."

The next also the biography of Robert at work..."
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Various opinions. Some thought it was a good opportunity, others what a grand adventure.

Some thought they were going for a little adventure, while others thought it was a good opportunity.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other groups)?

The whole family, father, mother, and children.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Naturally by boat and train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

Had several adventures on the way.

We overtook a band of Indians.

We met River boat and accompanied them into Ocean View and Red River.

Ramp Roseman at night and found the keeper in the dark room.

That was my first meeting with Indians.

15. Where did you first stop when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At what was called Woodworth, now known as Woodworth.

16. Where else did you settle or take up land?

On the north border of Plano and Round R.R.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No other place except for occasional trips out west to other parts of North America.

9 months to this day in 1948.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

I did not earn a living. I went to school at Dumbarton and then to college in Canada. I worked as a clerk for three years and homesteaded in 1902 and farmed since.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

Various opinions. Some thought it was a grand opportunity.

Some thought they were going to lose their homes.

The whole family came here from Manitoba in a cart.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends, or other acquaintances)?

By myself.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Naturally by boat and train.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents, or other experiences?)

We encountered a group of Indians.

We overtook a team of horses.

We met Ocean Man and his family.

Rumors of Indians at night as far as Prince Albert.

The keeper in the dark room.

Saw my first meeting with Indians.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

At the first house after arriving to become the first settlers of Hazelwood, Assiniboia.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

On the north border of Prince Albert, R.R.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

No other place except for 4 months in Prince Albert.

9 months in Prince Albert.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada?

I did not earn a living.

School at Dunrobin and then worked for 6 years at homestead.

Three years as farmer in 1902.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If not married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date you left St. Thomas at Winnipeg June 30th, 1918.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West at what time? When did they come and where they settled?

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

Plenty of experiences but none particularly good except the dunnage in 1900 out 1901 on Moon Creek. We had a deep snow last winter hill before any settlers came and we were one for several weeks at a time.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? By what means of travel?

We had to travel at first—town was forty miles away and when I moved to my home place two towns from Kinley—half after the railway was built—only six ten miles.

from Kinley
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date.

21. Did anyone else come to Sebastian County because of your recommendation it as a place to settle?

Yes

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West, tell when they came and where they settled.

23. In what particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory would you like to record?

Plenty of experiences but none about the summer of 1900 or 1901 on Moore Creek. Therein I was not near Deer House Hill before my settlers came and paid me one for several weeks at a time.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How far? By what means of travel?

We had to travel at first—town was forty miles away and from there to my home eleven times from Butler to Amasa. But after the railroad was built—only six ten miles.

from Kisler

26. If you owned a car before 1914, what did you buy it for? What makes?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Not so often

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?

31. Then (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently or did you make up your mind after trying it out? Than did you make this decision?

This was a question about the history of transportation and communication in a community. It asks about the first car used, the reasons for purchasing it, the trading center location, frequency of shopping, and the introduction of mail order catalogues and telephones. The last question explores the initial intentions of someone who came to Saskatchewan.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Not many. The land was being utilized or that line was not more moving in.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

No. We have a good family district. I am working in the

Questionnaire of our parents' locality

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

Yes. I was on the council of the

Municipality of Hazelwood for nine years

As the school board of Marmley

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mentioned, it has (giving dates whenever possible). (Such as owning the first automobile, organizing the first football team, etc.)

of John Scott and Mr. Conner

Not many. The land was being needed or that time was moving in.
